member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformAccelerationReader.GetTransform(Xen.Transform@)
member.summary: Get the most recently read transform

summary.para: Writes a series of structures to a binary stream, using lossy/lossless data compression
Prefer using this method of compression over for input data with rapidly changing, less predictable movement (commonly for animation data)
Redundant values are skipped and packed data types are used where possible
Compression levels are based on specified compression tolerances

remarks.para: Tolerance values may be changed at will, this will not corrupt data already written/about to be written

summary.para: Construct the writer with default values of:
ScaleTolerance = 0.025
TranslateTolerance = 0.01
RotationTolerance = 0.001

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Construct the writer

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.WriteUncompressed(Xen.Transform@,System.IO.BinaryWriter)
member.summary: Writes the entire transformation uncompressed. Normally the change in transform is written, relying on the previous value. (Writes 34 bytes)

remarks.para: This method can be used to 'reset' the compression stream.

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.WriteUncompressed(Xen.Transform,System.IO.BinaryWriter)
member.summary: Writes the entire transformation uncompressed. Normally the change in transform is written, relying on the previous value. Returns the number of bytes written (which is always 34 for this method)

remarks.para: This method can be used to 'reset' the compression stream.

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.EndWriting(System.IO.BinaryWriter)

summary.para: Write the final bytes that are needed to complete writing a series of transforms. Returns the number of bytes that were written

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.EndWriting(System.Byte[],System.Int32@)

summary.para: Write the final bytes that are needed to complete writing a series of transforms. Returns the number of bytes that were written

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.Write(Xen.Transform@,System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Write the transform to the stream. Returns the number of bytes, if any, that were written

param.name: forceWrite
param.para: If true, the method call will always write at least 1 byte
When false, multiple identical transforms may be represented with a write of a single byte at the end of the sequence

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.Write(Xen.Transform,System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Write the transform to the stream. Returns the number of bytes, if any, that were written

param.name: forceWrite
param.para: If true, the method call will always write at least 1 byte
When false, multiple identical transforms may be represented with a write of a single byte at the end of the sequence

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.Write(Xen.Transform@,System.Byte[],System.Int32@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Write the transform to a byte[] buffer. Returns the number of bytes, if any, that were written
member.param: index to begin writing to the buffer
buffer that transform data will be written to (this buffer should be at least 34 bytes in length)

param.name: forceWrite
param.para: If true, the method call will always write at least 1 byte
When false, multiple identical transforms may be represented with a write of a single byte at the end of the sequence

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.Write(Xen.Transform,System.Byte[],System.Int32@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Write the transform to a byte[] buffer. Returns the number of bytes, if any, that were written
member.param: index to begin writing to the buffer
buffer that transform data will be written to (this buffer should be at least 34 bytes in length)

param.name: forceWrite
param.para: If true, the method call will always write at least 1 byte
When false, multiple identical transforms may be represented with a write of a single byte at the end of the sequence

member.returns: Returns the number of bytes written

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.ScaleTolerance
member.summary: Gets/Sets the scale tolerance. This is the amount the scale needs to change for a new value to be compressed to the stream. Set to 0 for lossless writing

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.TranslateTolerance
member.summary: Gets/Sets the translate tolerance. This is the amount an translate x/y/z needs to change for a new value to be compressed to the stream. Set to 0 for lossless writing

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Compression.CompressedTransformWriter.RotationTolerance
member.summary: Gets/Sets the rotation tolerance. Rotations are stored as normalised vectors. This tolerance is for the change in a component of the vector. The maximum value is 0.5. However this would produce very infrequent rotations.

summary.para: Writes a series of structures to a binary stream as deltas, using lossy/lossless data compression
Prefer using this method of compression over for input data with smooth consistent movement that doesn't change velocity much over many samples, such as player movement
Redundant values are skipped and packed data types are used where possible
Compression levels are based on specified compression tolerances

remarks.para: Tolerance values may be changed at will, this will not corrupt data already written/about to be written
The and have higher overhead than the and

summary.para: Construct the writer with default values of:
ScaleTolerance = 0.025
TranslateTolerance = 0.01
RotationTolerance = 0.001

member.name: T:Xen.Ex.Filters.BlurFilter
member.summary: Applies a two pass, 16 sample vertical and horizontal texture blur filter to a draw target

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Filters.BlurFilter.#ctor(Xen.Ex.Filters.BlurFilterFormat,System.Single,Xen.Graphics.DrawTargetTexture2D,Xen.Graphics.DrawTargetTexture2D)
member.summary: Blur the source horizontally to the target, then blur vertically back to .
member.param: draw target to use as a temporary, intermediate target for blurring

param.name: bellCurveExponent
param.para: A scale value to infulence the bell curve used to generate the filter kernel.
A value of 1.0 generates a standard blur filter kernels. Larger values will produce a tighter curve, and less blur.
Smaller values will produce a wider curve, and a larger blur - but may produce a visible edge as the curve more rapidly ends.

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Filters.BlurFilter.#ctor(Xen.Ex.Filters.BlurFilterFormat,System.Single,Xen.Graphics.DrawTargetTexture2D,Xen.Graphics.DrawTargetTexture2D,Xen.Graphics.DrawTargetTexture2D)

member.param: draw target to use as a temporary, intermediate target for blurring

param.name: bellCurveExponent

A value of 1.0 generates a standard blur filter kernels. Larger values will produce a tighter curve, and less blur.
Smaller values will produce a wider curve, and a larger blur - but may produce a visible edge as the curve more rapidly ends.

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Filters.BlurFilter.Draw(Xen.FrameState)
member.summary: Apply the filter

summary.para: Set the filter format of the blur filter.

param.name: bellCurveExponent
param.para: A scale value to infulence the bell curve used to generate the filter kernel.
A value of 1.0 generates a standard blur filter kernels. Larger values will produce a tighter curve, and less blur.
Smaller values will produce a wider curve, and a larger blur - but may produce a visible edge as the curve more rapidly ends.

summary.para: Interface to a class that may modify the transforms of an avatars animation bone hierarchy, through a
Note: Methods implemented for this interface should be thread safe
Modify the bones of the animation before the animation is processed. Returning false will prevent the animation / blending process from starting.
Use this method to replace the entire animation, and prevent the standard animations from being processed.
Any modifications to will have no effect unless false is returned.

param.name: boneWorldSpaceIdentityTransforms
param.para: The world space transforms of the bones
If no animations are playing, all bones will be Identity transforms. These transforms are their world space default transforms

summary.para: Modify the animation bones of a mesh

param.name: boneWorldSpaceIdentityTransforms
param.para: The world space transforms of the bones
If no animations are playing, all bones will be Identity transforms. These transforms are their world space default transforms

summary.para: Modify the animation bones of a mesh, after they have been transformed into bone-world space hierarchy
Note: Before calling , the bones will be transformed by their hieracrchy. This process is not required otherwise. Modifying a bone will have no effect on the rendererd avatar.
This method will be most useful for getting the world position of avatar bones, to place props, etc.
When true, will be called after bones have been processed.
Note: Before calling , the bones will be transformed by their hieracrchy. This process is not required otherwise. Modifying a bone will have no effect on the rendererd avatar.
This method will be most useful for getting the world position of avatar bones, to place props, etc.

summary.para: Interface to a class that may modify the transforms of a models animation bone hierarchy, through a
Note: Methods implemented for this interface should be thread safe
Modify the bones of the animation before the animation is processed. Returning false will prevent the animation / blending process from starting.
Use this method to replace the entire animation, and prevent the standard animations from being processed.
Any modifications to will have no effect unless false is returned.

param.para: The world space transforms of the bones
If no animations are playing, all bones will be Identity transforms. These transforms are their world space default transforms

The weighting of this animation instance. 1.0f by default.
When set to 0.0, the animation will have no effect. If set to 0.5f, the animation will only have a 50 percent effect on rotations, translations, etc.

summary.para: Gets/Sets a culling proxy, to cull test this particle system
Due to their nature, particle systems do not know their bouding voumes, so cannot cull test themselves
Set this property to a non-null value to override the blend state defined in the particle XML
Note: All particle drawers perform RGB * Alpha modulation in the pixel shader, should be set in place of .

implements the method to draw cpu particles
Draws 3D particles as Billboard Sprites (Rotation is generated per particle)
Particles will be scaled by thier velocity length, and rotated in the direction they are travelling
For use with a instance.

This method is only present on Windows builds

summary.para: This class provides Hotloading support to particle systems
Hotloading will automatically reload the particle system if the source file changes (at runtime)
This allows runtime editing/tweaking of particle system effects
Call to begin monitoring the system

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Graphics.Content.ParticleSystemHotLoader.Monitor(Xen.UpdateManager,Xen.Ex.Graphics.ParticleSystem,System.String)
member.summary:
Begin monitoring the particle system for hotloading
Note: The path to the xen shader system .dlls must be specified. The shader compiler has to be loaded dynamically for hotloading, and only works with a full installation of XNA GameStudio
member.param: File path to the compiled xen shader system .dlls

member.summary: Interface to a light created in a

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Material.IMaterialLight.Colour
member.summary: Gets/Sets the diffuse colour of the light (Vector3)

member.summary: Gets/Sets the specular colour of the light (Vector3)

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Material.IMaterialLight.SpecularPowerScaler
member.summary: Gets/Sets a scale factor for the material specular power (default is 1, no change)

summary.para: (Advanced) Gets/Sets a floating point value that can be used to adjust the rendering priority of a light.
When a material shader cannot display all lights directly, lights it deems low priority will be displayed as ambient lighting
This priority is calculated by the brightness and distance of the light. Adjust this value to bias the priority of this specific light.
This value defaults to 1

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Material.IMaterialPointLight.Position
member.summary: Gets/Sets the position of the point light

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Material.IMaterialPointLight.SourceRadius
member.summary:
Gets/Sets the light anttenuation (falloff) source radius. The light is simulated as a spherical source.
The larger the radius, the brighter the light and softer the falloff will be
This value must be greater than 0

summary.para: The model will be displayed with per-pixel lighting
This is generally the slowest rendering mode
The model will be displayed with per-vertex lighting
This is generally faster than the Per-Pixel rendering mode, unless the model has a very high polygon count, or is very small on screen
The model will be displayed with only ambient spherical harmonic lighting
This is the fastest way to light a model, however it is generally low accuracy

summary.para: This is a very simple class that will draw wireframe outlines of cull tests that have been performed
This class is intended to be used as a DrawTarget modifier (). Add it to a draw target with

remarks.para: This class works by acting as both a DrawTarget Modifier and a PostCuller cull test primitive
A DrawTarget Modifier is setup/shutdown when the DrawTarget begins/finishes rendering. (see )

During the setup phase, this class adds itself as a PostCuller to the DrawTarget (see DrawState.Cullers.PushPostCuller, this allows the class to record the bounding boxes and spheres used for successful CullTests performed
During the shutdown phase, this class draws the recorded sphers/cubes.

summary.para: Construct the Visualizer. This class displays the cull tests that have been performed.
Add the constructed instance of this class to a DrawTarget as a Modifier using

member.summary: Begin the modifier (This method is called by the DrawTarget)

member.name: M:Xen.Ex.Scene.CullTestVisualizer.End(Xen.DrawState)
member.summary: End the modifier (This method is called by the DrawTarget)

summary.para: Gets/Set if the visualization is enabled

member.name: P:Xen.Ex.Scene.CullTestVisualizer.EnableDepthTesting
member.summary: When false, the displayed cull tests will have depth testing disabled - so they are always visible

members.member:
A DrawPredicate uses a to cull drawing of a 'complex' object based on the number of pixels a 'predicate' object draws
If the predicate object (usually simple bounding geometry) draws more than , the (usually more complex) object will be dawn
r
An example use of this class would be drawing complex geometry, using a much simpler drawable (say, a bounding box) as the predicate.
When rendering, the predicate will be drawn every few frames (colour and depth writing will be disabled). While drawing the predicate, an occlusion query will be active.
The occlusion query results are returned several frames later. The result is the number of pixels drawn (the number of pixels drawn by the predicate).
If the number of pixels drawn is greater than , then the complex object will be drawn.
This means that if the predicate is occluded while rendering (NOTE: closer objects must still be drawn before it) then the complex object won't be rendered at all.
Note, there are several requirements for a DrawPredicate to improve performance:
The predicate must be drawn in order such that potential occluders are drawn first (eg, front to back).
The main item must be complex enough, and occluded often enough such that the overhead of drawing the predicate is actually worth while. (If you are fill rate limited, a DrawPredicate will probably not help at all)
Finally, the potential delay between the oclusion query result being returned may produce a delay where the object isn't drawn.
Finally, note that when the predicate is off screen (as reported by it's cull test) the query result gets reset. When the predicate is on screen again, the query is assumed to have passed. This can be disabled by setting to false. When false, the complex object may be invisible for the first few frames when appearing from off screen. When true, when comming back on screen, the complex object may be drawn even though occluded. (The default is false)

summary.para: A structure storing a 9 constant (L2) RGB sperhical harmonic. See remarks for details.
An L2 SH is significantly more accurate than an L1 SH, however it is also significantly more complex to calculate and display.

remarks.para: L1 and L2 Spherical harmonics are useful for storing approximate lighiting information.

They work by storing the an approximation of of a lighting function over a sphere.
Where as most approximations work in one or two dimensions (for example, approximations to sin/cos), a sherical harmonic is an approximation of an RGB (red/blue/green) function that maps to a sphere.
The most common use of an L2 spherical harmonic is to efficiently encode directional lighting information at a point. Another method to achieve this would be to use a Cube Map. An SH works well as a substitute, as it typically will use much less data, and produces a smoother output.
Spherical harmonics also have the advantage they can be efficiently added together, multiplied, lerped, etc.

An example of how an SH can be used to store lighting information:
In a game, it may be desirable that an object is lit by multiple nearby lights. However, it may be too inefficient to light the object with every light.
An approximation to this lighting, would be to use a SH. Given the centre point of the object, if there are 8 lights nearby, then call once for each light. This will store the approximate contribution of that light (for it's given direction) in the SH function. Sampling the SH (usually in the vertex shader) will produce an approximation for the input lights, however it will be much cheaper than sampling each light for every pixel.
Consider the following code example:

In the above example, white RGB light in the positive X direction is added to an blank SH.
The SH is then sampled three times, in the positive / negative X axis, and also the Y axis.
The output of the SH will be very close to (1,1,1) in the positive X axis (as is desired, as this is the direction of the input light).
The output of the SH in the negative X and positive Y axis will be close to zero (as no light is coming from these directions).
Note, the outputs will not be exactly one or zero (as it's an approximation!).
Note that AddLight can be called as often as desired, which is useful to accumulate ligth from multiple sources.

summary.para: Use this function after accumulating multiple lights with the AddLight method.
This method averages all the calls to AddLight() based on the accumulated weighting, assuming they were light input over a sphere.
For example, if generating a spherical harmonic from a cube map, treat each pixel as a light source by calling AddLight(), then call this method to get the average for entire the sphere.
